[He]145-boyne turned back to [Mrs. Sellars]163-mrs. sellars . “[127-judith] Are n’t [you]1562-you getting rather sick of [this place]2814-this place ? ” [he]145-boyne asked abruptly . [She]163-mrs. sellars gave back [his]145-boyne irritated stare with one of genuine surprise . “[1562-you] Sick of what ? [You]1562-you mean of [Cortina]34-cortina ? ” “[1562-you] Of the whole show . ” [His]145-boyne sweeping gesture gathered up in one contemptuous handful the vast panorama of mountain , [vale and forest]3623-vale and forest . “[0-i] [I]0-i always feel that when scenery gets mixed up with [our]1564-our personal bothers all the virtue goes out of it — as if [our]1564-our worries were so many locusts , eating everything bare . ” [Mrs. Sellars]163-mrs. sellars was silent for a moment ; then [her]163-mrs. sellars hand fell on [his]145-boyne . “[0-i] [I]0-i ’ve always been afraid , [dear]2469-dear , that this queer responsibility [you]2469-dear ’ve assumed was going to end by getting on [your]2469-dear nerves — ” [Boyne]145-boyne jumped up , drawing abruptly away from [her]163-mrs. sellars . “[200-mr. dobree] Responsibility ? What responsibility ? ” [He]145-boyne walked across [the room]1180-the room , turned back , and awkwardly laid an answering caress on [her]163-mrs. sellars hair . “[248-gammon] [Gammon]248-gammon ! It ’s [Mr. Dobree]200-mr. dobree who gets on [my]0-i nerves — just a little . ” ( “[200-mr. dobree] Hypocrite ! ” [he]145-boyne cursed [himself]145-boyne inwardly . ) “[200-mr. dobree] Fact is , [I]0-i liked [Cortina]34-cortina a damned sight better when [you]2469-dear and [I]0-i and [the children]505-the children had it all to [ourselves]1567-ourselves . ” [He]145-boyne saw the light of reassurance in [her]163-mrs. sellars averted cheek . “[0-i] Just [my]0-i beastly selfishness , [I]0-i know — [I]0-i need n’t tell [you]2469-dear that [men]2842-men _ are _ beastly selfish , need [I]0-i ? ” [He]145-boyne laughed , and [her]163-mrs. sellars faint laugh echoed [his]145-boyne . “[0-i] [Mr. Dobree]200-mr. dobree is going soon , [I]0-i believe , ” [she]163-mrs. sellars volunteered . [Boyne]145-boyne pulled [himself]145-boyne together . “[200-mr. dobree] Well , that makes it a good deal easier to be unselfish while [he]200-mr. dobree ’s [here]2434-here , and [I]0-i take it upon [myself]0-i to accept [his]200-mr. dobree picnic for to - morrow . [I]0-i ’ll drop down and announce it to [the children]505-the children . ” [He]145-boyne flattered [himself]145-boyne that [his]145-boyne simulation of buoyancy had produced the desired effect , and that [his]145-boyne parting from [Mrs. Sellars]163-mrs. sellars was unclouded . But halfway down [the hill]3071-the hill [he]145-boyne stood suddenly still in [the path]3626-the path , and exclaimed aloud : “[0-i] But after [he]200-mr. dobree ’s gone ; what then ? ” The picnic was beautifully successful — one of those smooth creaseless well - oiled successes as to which one feels that at any moment it may slip from one ’s hold and reveal the face of failure . A very Janus of a picnic , [Boyne]145-boyne thought .... To [the chief actors]3627-the chief actors , however , it presented no such duality , but was the perfect image of what constitutes A Good Time For [The Young People]3628-the young people , when made out of the happy union of tact and money . To [Mr. Dobree]200-mr. dobree it was certainly that , and [he]200-mr. dobree was justified in feeling that if [you]3629-you order the two roomiest and most balloon - tired motors obtainable , and fill enough hampers with the most succulent delicacies of [a “[0-i] Palace ” restaurant]3630-a “ palace ” restaurant , and are actuated throughout by the kindliest desire to give pleasure , happiness will automatically follow . As regards [the younger members of the party]3631-the younger members of the party , it undoubtedly did . [Terry]198-terry was strong enough to enjoy the long day on [the heights]1499-the heights without fear of [Miss Scope]147-miss scope ’s thermometer ; [Blanca]128-blanca was impressed by the lavish fare which replaced [their]3631-the younger members of the party habitual bread and chocolate ; and [the small children]3633-the small children were in the state of effervescence induced by freedom from lessons and the sense of being [the central figures of the day]3634-the central figures of the day . And [Judith]127-judith — ? After lunch [the younger members of the party]3631-the younger members of the party trailed away with [Miss Scope]147-miss scope to hunt for wild strawberries while [the others]2515-the others sat pillowed in moss beside [a silver waterfall]3637-a silver waterfall . [Boyne]145-boyne , supine against [his]145-boyne boulder , studied the scene and meditated from behind a screen of pipe smoke . [Judith]127-judith , a little way off , leaned luxuriously against [her]127-judith mossy cushion , [her]127-judith hat tossed aside , [her]127-judith head resting in the curve of an immature arm . [Her]127-judith profile looked small and clear against the auburn tremor of bracken turned inward by the rush of the water . A live rose burned in [her]127-judith cheeks , darkening [her]127-judith eyebrows and lashes , and putting a velvet shadow under [her]127-judith closed lids . [She]127-judith had fallen asleep , and sleep surrendered [her]127-judith unguarded to [[her]127-judith watchers]3638-her watchers . “[1571-she] [She]1571-she looks almost grown up — [she]1571-she looks kissable . Why should [she]1571-she , all of a sudden ? ” [Boyne]145-boyne asked [himself]145-boyne , suddenly disturbed , not by [her]1571-she increased prettiness ( the measure of that varied from hour to hour ) but by some new quality in it . [He]145-boyne turned [his]145-boyne eyes away , and they fell on [Mr. Dobree]200-mr. dobree , who sat facing [him]145-boyne in the studied _ abandon _ of a picnicker unused to picnics . [Mr. Dobree]200-mr. dobree ’s inexhaustible wardrobe had supplied [him]145-boyne with just the slightly shabby homespun suit and slightly faded hat adapted to the occasion ; and [Boyne]145-boyne wondered whether it were this change of dress which made [him]200-mr. dobree also seem different . But no : the difference was deeper . Despite [his]200-mr. dobree country clothes , [Mr. Dobree]200-mr. dobree did not look easier or less urban ; [he]200-mr. dobree merely looked more excited and off [his]200-mr. dobree guard . [His]200-mr. dobree clear cautious eyes had grown blurred and furtive ; one could almost see a faint line stretching from them to the recumbent [Judith]127-judith . Along that line it was manifest that [Mr. Dobree]200-mr. dobree ’s thoughts were racing ; and [Boyne]145-boyne knew they were the same thoughts as [his]145-boyne own . The discovery shocked [him]145-boyne indescribably . But [he]145-boyne remembered that the levelling tendencies of modern life have levelled differences of age with the rest ; and that [Mr. Dobree]200-mr. dobree was , to all intents and purposes , but little older than [himself]200-mr. dobree . Moreover , [he]200-mr. dobree was still brisk and muscular ; [his]200-mr. dobree glance was habitually alert ; in spite of [his]200-mr. dobree silver hair there seemed no reason why [he]200-mr. dobree should not share with [Boyne]145-boyne the contemplation of [Judith]127-judith ’s defenceless beauty . But if this was [Boyne]145-boyne ’s conclusion it was apparently not [Mr. Dobree]200-mr. dobree ’s . As [Boyne]145-boyne continued to observe [him]1572-himself , [Mr. Dobree]200-mr. dobree ’s habitual pinkness turned to a red which suffused even [his]200-mr. dobree temples and eyelids , so that [his]200-mr. dobree carefully brushed white hair looked like a sunlit cloud against an angry sky . But with whom was [Mr. Dobree]200-mr. dobree angry ? Why , with [himself]1572-himself , manifestly . [His]200-mr. dobree eyes still rested on the dreaming [Judith]127-judith ; but the rest of [his]200-mr. dobree face looked as if every muscle were tightened in the effort to pull the eyes away . “[1571-she] [He]1572-himself ’s frightened — [he]1572-himself ’s frightened at [himself]1572-himself , ” [Boyne]145-boyne thought , calling to mind — with a faint recoil from the reminder — that [he]200-mr. dobree also , once or twice , had been vaguely afraid of [himself]200-mr. dobree when [he]200-mr. dobree had looked too long at [Judith]127-judith . Had [his]200-mr. dobree eyes been like that , [he]145-boyne wondered ? And the muscles of [his]200-mr. dobree face been stretched in the effort to detach the eyes ? The thing was not pleasant to visualise ; and [he]145-boyne disliked [Mr. Dobree]200-mr. dobree the more for serving as [his]200-mr. dobree mirror .... But suddenly [Mr. Dobree]200-mr. dobree was on [his]200-mr. dobree feet , [his]200-mr. dobree whole attention given to [Mrs. Sellars]163-mrs. sellars . Again [Boyne]145-boyne followed [his]200-mr. dobree change of direction with a start . [Mrs. Sellars]163-mrs. sellars — but then [she]163-mrs. sellars had been [there]2439-there all the time ! Shadowed by [her]163-mrs. sellars spreading hat , [her]163-mrs. sellars light body bedded in the turf , [she]163-mrs. sellars looked almost as young and sylvan as [Judith]127-judith . But somehow [she]163-mrs. sellars had been merged in the landscape , all broken up into a dapple of sun and shade , of murmurs and soughings : [her]163-mrs. sellars way of fitting into things sometimes had this effect of effacing [her]163-mrs. sellars . [She]163-mrs. sellars lifted [her]163-mrs. sellars head , and in the shade of the hat - brim [Boyne]145-boyne caught a delicate watchfulness of brows and lips , as of tiny live things under a protecting leaf . [Mr. Dobree]200-mr. dobree was challenging [her]1573-you jauntily . “[1572-himself] Do [you]1573-you see why [those young cannibals]1574-those young cannibals should monopolise all the wild strawberries ? Suppose [we]1575-we leave [Mr. Boyne]145-boyne to mount guard over the sleeping beauty , and try to bag [our]1575-we share before it ’s too late ? ” The words said clearly enough : “[145-boyne] Take [me]0-i away — it ’s high time , ” and [Mrs. Sellars]163-mrs. sellars ’s gay little answer : “[145-boyne] Come on — [I’ll]1576-i’ll show [you]1573-you a patch [they]1574-those young cannibals ’ll never find , ” seemed to declare as clearly : “[0-i] [I]0-i know ; but [I]0-i ’ll see that [you]1573-you do n’t come to any mischief . ” [She]163-mrs. sellars was on [her]163-mrs. sellars feet before [his]145-boyne hands could help [her]163-mrs. sellars up ; something light and bounding in [her]163-mrs. sellars seemed to spring to [his]145-boyne call . “[1573-you] This way , this way , ” [she]163-mrs. sellars cried , starting ahead of [him]145-boyne up the boulder - strewn way . [Boyne]145-boyne heard [their]1575-we voices mounting [the streamside]3640-the streamside , mingling with the noise of the water , fading and flashing out again like the glimpses of [her]163-mrs. sellars dress through the beech - leaves . [He]145-boyne lay without moving , watching the smoke of [his]145-boyne pipe rise in wavering spirals , twisted out of shape by puffs of air from the waterfall . With [Mr. Dobree]200-mr. dobree ’s withdrawal the ideas suggested by [his]145-boyne presence had gone too ; [Judith Wheater]127-judith seemed once more [a little girl]3641-a little girl . Though perplexities and uncertainties still lingered on the verge of [Boyne]145-boyne ’s mind [his]145-boyne central self was anchored in a deep circle of peace . Every fibre of [him]145-boyne was alive to the exquisite moment ; but [he]145-boyne had no need to fly from it , no fear of its flying from [him]145-boyne . [Judith]127-judith ’s sleep was a calm pool in which [he]145-boyne rested . [He]145-boyne fancied [he]145-boyne must have been watching [her]127-judith for a long time , [his]145-boyne thoughts enclosing [her]127-judith in a sort of calm fraternal vigilance , when [she]127-judith opened [her]127-judith eyes and turned them on [him]145-boyne , still dewy with sleep . “[193-martin] [Martin]193-martin ! ” [she]127-judith hailed [him]145-boyne drowsily ; then , fully awake , [she]127-judith sat up and exclaimed : “[3107-darling] [Darling]3107-darling , when are [you]193-martin going to be married ? [I]0-i ’ve positively got to know at once . ” [She]127-judith was always startling [Boyne]145-boyne , but [she]127-judith had perhaps never startled [him]145-boyne more than by this question ; for even as [she]127-judith spoke [he]145-boyne had been half unconsciously putting it to [himself]145-boyne . [He]145-boyne remembered , as something already far off , picturesque and unreal as a youthful folly , [his]145-boyne resentment of [Mrs. Sellars]163-mrs. sellars ’s delay in fixing a date for [their]3642-they marriage . Was it only two or three weeks ago that [he]145-boyne had sent [her]127-judith , with a basket of gentians picked on a lofty upland , a quotation from [Marvell]249-marvell ’s “[0-i] Coy Mistress ” ? Now all that seemed [an undergraduate]3643-an undergraduate ’s impatience . [She]127-judith had taught [him]145-boyne that [they]3642-they were very well as [they]3642-they were , and if [he]145-boyne still asked [himself]145-boyne when [they]3642-they were to be married , the question had imperceptibly taken another form . “[0-i] What in [God]214-god ’s name will become of [the children]505-the children after [we]1579-we ’re married ? ” was the way [he]145-boyne now instinctively put it . [He]145-boyne too sat up , and gazed into [Judith]127-judith ’s sleepy eyes . As [he]145-boyne did so [he]145-boyne was aware that an uncomfortable redness ( which did not , [he]145-boyne hoped , resemble [Mr. Dobree]200-mr. dobree ’s ) was creeping up to [his]145-boyne temples . “[0-i] When [I]0-i ’m going to be married ? Why ? What ’s the odds ? [I]0-i do n’t know that it ’s [anybody]2661-anybody ’s business , anyhow , ” [he]145-boyne grumbled in an ill - assured voice . [Judith]127-judith brushed the rebuff aside . “[0-i] Oh , but it is — it ’s [mine]0-i . For a very particular reason , ” [she]127-judith continued , as if affectionately resolved to break down the barrier of [his]145-boyne reserve . “[0-i] A reason ? Nonsense ! What has a chit like [you]0-i got to do with reasons ? ” “[0-i] [You]0-i mean [I]0-i ’m so unreasonable ? ” A quick shadow crossed [her]127-judith face . “[0-i] [You]0-i did n’t really mean that ? ” “[0-i] [I]0-i did n’t mean anything at all — any more than [you]0-i do . [I]0-i only meant : why are n’t [we]1581-we very well as [we]1581-we are ? ” [Her]127-judith eyes grew wide at this , and continued to fix [him]145-boyne with a half mocking gravity , while [her]127-judith lips rounded into a smile . “[0-i] Oh , but , [Martin]193-martin dear , it ’s [Mrs. Sellars]163-mrs. sellars who ought to say that — not [you]193-martin ! ” [Boyne]145-boyne burst out laughing . How could one ever keep serious for two minutes with [any of [these preposterous children]3645-these preposterous children]3644-any of these preposterous children ? And once more [he]145-boyne told [himself]145-boyne that [Judith]127-judith was as preposterous , and as much of [a child]435-a child , as [the youngest of [them]3645-these preposterous children]3522-the youngest of them . “[163-mrs. sellars] [You]193-martin know , [darling]3107-darling , [you]3107-darling ought to be _ empressé _ , impatient , passionate , ” [she]127-judith adjured [him]145-boyne , as if [his]145-boyne very life depended on [his]145-boyne following [her]127-judith advice . [He]145-boyne leaned on [his]145-boyne elbow and examined [her]127-judith with deliberation . “[3107-darling] Well , of all the cheek — ! ” [She]127-judith shook [her]127-judith head , still smiling . “[3107-darling] [I]0-i ’m not cheeky ; [I]0-i ’m really not , [Martin]193-martin . But sometimes [you]193-martin strike [me]0-i as having so little experience — ” ( “[193-martin] Thank [you]193-martin , ” [Boyne]145-boyne interjected . ) “[193-martin] Oh , [I]0-i mean in those sorts of ways . [Doll Westway]166-doll westway always said [I]0-i had no tact . And all [I]0-i wanted was to explain why [I]0-i have to know as soon as possible when [you]193-martin ’re to be married . ” “[0-i] Well , [you]193-martin certainly have n’t explained that , ” [Boyne]145-boyne answered , turning away from [her]193-martin to relight [his]145-boyne pipe . “[193-martin] No ; but [I]0-i ’m going to . And [you]193-martin ’ll be pleased . It ’s because [we]1585-we ’ve all clubbed together — even the steps and [Scopy]132-scopy have — to give [you]193-martin a really jolly wedding present ; and [I]0-i think [you]193-martin ’ll like what [we]1585-we ’ve found . [He]3650-he met the question with another laugh . “[193-martin] Love presents ? [I]0-i should think [I]0-i did ! Almost as much as [you]193-martin do . ” [She]0-i coloured a little at the insinuation ; and perceiving this , [he]3650-he hastened on : “[193-martin] It ’s awfully dear of [you]193-martin all , and [I]0-i ’m ever so grateful . But there was no need to be in such a devil of a hurry . ” [Her]0-i face became all sympathy and interrogation . “[193-martin] Oh , [Martin]193-martin , [you]193-martin do n’t mean — things have n’t gone wrong , have they ? ” [Her]0-i look and intonation showed that [she]0-i would have been genuinely distressed if [they]3651-they had . A pang like neuralgia shot through [Boyne]145-boyne — yet a pang that was not all bitter . [He]145-boyne took [her]0-i hand , and laid what [she]0-i had once called a “[193-martin] grown up kiss ” on it . “[2469-dear] Of course not , [dear]2469-dear . Only , [you]2469-dear know , there ’s really no sort of hurry . ” [She]0-i met this in silence , as something manifestly final . Folding [her]0-i arms behind [her]0-i , [she]0-i let [her]0-i head droop back on them , and [her]0-i gaze wandered lazily skyward through the flicker of boughs . [Boyne]145-boyne had got [his]145-boyne pipe going again . Gradually the tumult in [his]145-boyne mind subsided . [He]145-boyne sank back lazily at [her]0-i side , tilting [his]145-boyne hat over [his]145-boyne brows , and saying to [himself]145-boyne : “[2469-dear] What [on earth]1588-on earth ’s the use of thinking ahead , anyhow ? ” Directly in the line of [his]145-boyne vision , [Judith]127-judith ’s sandalled feet lay in a bed of bracken , crossed like a resting Mercury ’s . [He]145-boyne could almost see the little tufted wings at the heels . For the moment [his]145-boyne imagination was imprisoned in a circle close about them . XXI That evening , when [the children , weary but still jubilant]3652-the children , weary but still jubilant , had been dropped at [the _ Pension Rosenglüh _]3070-the _ pension rosenglüh _ , and [Boyne]145-boyne had joined [Mrs. Sellars]163-mrs. sellars for a late dinner at [the _ châlet _]911-the _ châlet _ , the first thing that struck [him]145-boyne was that [his]145-boyne sapphire had reappeared on [her]0-i hand . [He]145-boyne wondered afterward how it was that [he]145-boyne , in general so unobservant of such details , had noticed that [she]0-i had resumed the modest stone ; and concluded that it was because of [Judith]127-judith ’s ridiculous cross - examination about the date of [his]145-boyne marriage . [He]145-boyne almost suspected that , baffled by [his]145-boyne evasiveness , [the pertinacious child]3655-the pertinacious child had ended by addressing [herself]3655-the pertinacious child to [Mrs. Sellars]163-mrs. sellars , and that [the latter , thus challenged]3656-the latter , thus challenged , had put on [her]0-i ring . But no — though [Judith]127-judith was sometimes lacking in tact ( as [she]127-judith [herself]127-judith acknowledged ) this indiscretion could not be imputed to [her]127-judith , for the reason that [Mrs. Sellars]163-mrs. sellars — [Boyne]145-boyne remembered it only now — had not reappeared on the scene till it was time to pack [the sleepy picnickers]3657-the sleepy picnickers into [the motors]3658-the motors . [She]127-judith and [Mr. Dobree]200-mr. dobree had been a long time away . [They]3659-their had apparently prolonged [their]3659-their walk , and , incidentally , had failed to find the promised strawberries — or else had consumed them on the spot . And on the way [home]290-home [Judith]127-judith and [Mrs. Sellars]163-mrs. sellars had not been in [the same car]3661-the same car . Why , then , had [Mrs. Sellars]163-mrs. sellars suddenly put on [her]163-mrs. sellars ring ? [Boyne]145-boyne would only suppose that [she]127-judith had decided , for reasons unknown to [him]145-boyne , to announce [their]3659-their engagement that night to [Mr. Dobree]200-mr. dobree , who was no doubt going to join [them]3659-their at dinner . The idea obscurely irritated [Boyne]145-boyne ; [he]145-boyne felt bored in advance by the neat and obvious things [Mr. Dobree]200-mr. dobree would consider it becoming to say . [Boyne]145-boyne ’s whole view of [[Mrs. Sellars]163-mrs. sellars ’s friend]3662-mrs. sellars ’s friend had been changed by [his]145-boyne sudden glimpse of [the man who had looked out of [Mr. Dobree]200-mr. dobree]3663-the man who had looked out of mr. dobree ’s eyes at [Judith]127-judith . Before that , [Boyne]145-boyne had pigeon - holed [him]3663-the man who had looked out of mr. dobree as [the successful lawyer]3664-the successful lawyer , able in [his]3663-the man who had looked out of mr. dobree profession , third - rate in other capacities , with a methodically planned existence of which professional affairs filled the larger part , and the rest was divided up like a carefully - weighed vitamin diet ( [Mr. Dobree]200-mr. dobree was strong on vitamins ) between exercise , society , philanthropy and travel . Now , a long way off down this fair perspective , [a small , an almost invisible Dobree]3665-a small , an almost invisible dobree , lurked and prowled , staring as [he]200-mr. dobree had stared at [Judith]127-judith . A sudden irritation filled [Boyne]145-boyne at the thought of what , unknown to [Mrs. Sellars]163-mrs. sellars , peered and grimaced behind [[her]163-mrs. sellars legal counsellor]3666-her legal counsellor . It was as if [Mr. Dobree]200-mr. dobree had unconsciously evoked for [him]200-mr. dobree some tragic allegory of [Judith]127-judith ’s future .... “[2469-dear] Where ’s [[your]1589-you friend]2832-your friend ? Are [we]1591-we waiting for [him]2832-your friend ? ” [Boyne]145-boyne ’s question sounded abrupt in [his]145-boyne own ears , but was received by [Mrs. Sellars]163-mrs. sellars with [her]163-mrs. sellars usual equanimity . “[1591-we] [Mr. Dobree]200-mr. dobree ? No , [we]1591-we ’re not waiting for [him]2832-your friend . [He]2832-your friend ’s not coming . ” [Boyne]145-boyne felt relieved , yet vaguely baffled . If [Dobree]200-mr. dobree was n’t coming ( [he]145-boyne immediately thought ) , why the devil was n’t [he]2832-your friend ? And what was [he]2832-your friend up to instead ? “[2832-your friend] Chucked [you]1589-you for a party at [the ‘ Palace]1592-the ‘ palace , ’ [I]0-i suppose ? It was indeed uncommonly pleasant to be alone with [her]3621-his betrothed again . [She]3621-his betrothed gratified [him]145-boyne , at the outset , by praising the behaviour of [the children on the picnic]3668-the children on the picnic ; and as [they]1593-they talked [he]145-boyne began to think that [his]145-boyne growing irritability , and [his]145-boyne odd reluctance to look forward to [their]1593-they future together , had been caused only by the intrusion of irrelevant problems and [people]463-people . “[0-i] When [we]1593-they ’re alone together everything ’s always all right , ” [he]145-boyne thought , reassured . [He]145-boyne saw that [Rose Sellars]162-rose sellars knew [he]145-boyne was glad to be alone with [her]127-judith , and that the knowledge put [her]127-judith at [her]127-judith ease , and made [her]127-judith want to say and do whatever would maintain that mood in [him]145-boyne . [Marry Dobree]250-marry dobree — [you]0-i ? ” “[0-i] [You]0-i see [you]0-i were right : [he]200-mr. dobree does want to get married , ” [she]0-i softly bantered . “[200-mr. dobree] It was what [he]200-mr. dobree came for — to ask [me]0-i . [Boyne]145-boyne laughed again , this time at [himself]145-boyne . “[200-mr. dobree] [I]0-i do n’t know what [you]0-i see in it that is so absurd , ” [Mrs. Sellars]163-mrs. sellars murmured , a faint note of vexation in [her]0-i voice . [He]145-boyne noticed that [she]163-mrs. sellars had grown unusually pale . [She]163-mrs. sellars sat down beside the table , and began turning over the letters and papers which the evening post had brought . But all [he]145-boyne could see was the sapphire ring , re - established , enthroned , proclaiming [his]145-boyne own destiny to all concerned and unconcerned . “[1612-you] So [you]1612-you told [him]1613-him [you]1612-you were already engaged ? ” [She]163-mrs. sellars looked up at [him]145-boyne . “[1612-you] It was only fair , was n’t it ? ” “[1612-you] Certainly — that is , if being engaged was the only obstacle . ” “[200-mr. dobree] The only obstacle ? ” “[200-mr. dobree] If [you]1612-you were prepared to marry [Dobree]200-mr. dobree , supposing [you]1612-you ’d still been free . ” [She]163-mrs. sellars weighed this , and then laughed a little , but without much gaiety . “[200-mr. dobree] How do [I]0-i know what [I]0-i should have done if [I]0-i ’d been free ? ” [He]145-boyne continued to look at [her]163-mrs. sellars . “[200-mr. dobree] Do [you]1612-you want to try ? ” The colour rose to [her]163-mrs. sellars forehead . [She]163-mrs. sellars dropped the letters , and composed [her]163-mrs. sellars hands on them as if in the effort to control a secret agitation . “[1612-you] Is this a way of telling [me]0-i [you]1612-you ’re vexed because [I]0-i announced [our]1614-our engagement to [Mr. Dobree]200-mr. dobree ? ” [He]145-boyne hesitated , feeling ( and now [he]145-boyne hated [himself]145-boyne for feeling ) that it was a moment for going warily . “[200-mr. dobree] Not vexed ; that ’s not the word . Only [I]0-i did agree with [you]1612-you that , as long as — as nothing about [our]1614-our future was definitely settled — it was ever so much pleasanter keeping [our]1614-our private affairs to [ourselves]1614-our . It ’s just the feeling — ” “[0-i] The feeling that [some one else]3565-some one else is in [our]1614-our secret ? But [all the Wheater children]1616-all the wheater children have been — for a long time . ” [She]1612-you spoke the words ever so lightly , as if [she]1612-you had barely pencilled them on a smooth page . [Boyne]145-boyne was startled . [He]145-boyne could see no analogy , but did not know how to explain that there was none . “[1616-all the wheater children] Oh , [the children]505-the children ; but [the children]505-the children do n’t count . Besides , that was n’t [my]0-i fault . [Judith]127-judith guessed . ” [He]145-boyne smiled a little at the reminiscence . “[127-judith] But perhaps [Mr. Dobree]200-mr. dobree guessed , ” [he]145-boyne added , with a return of ease . [Mrs. Sellars]163-mrs. sellars gave another little laugh . “[127-judith] Oh , no ; [Mr. Dobree]200-mr. dobree did n’t guess . [I]0-i had to dot the _ [i]0-i _ ’s for [him]200-mr. dobree . The fact is”—she paused a moment—“he[0-i] was convinced that [you]0-i were in love with [Judith Wheater]127-judith . ” Instantly all the resentments and suspicions which [Boyne]145-boyne had dismissed rushed back on [him]145-boyne . [He]145-boyne had been right , then — [he]145-boyne had not mistaken the signs and portents . As if they were ever mistakable ! “[127-judith] How rotten , ” [he]145-boyne said in a low voice . [Mrs. Sellars]163-mrs. sellars dropped one of the letters which [she]163-mrs. sellars had absently taken up again . “[193-martin] [Martin]193-martin — ” “[193-martin] Rotten . The mere thinking of such a thing — much less insinuating it to [any one else]1619-any one else . But it just shows — ” [He]145-boyne broke off , and then began again , on a fresh wave of indignation : “[200-mr. dobree] Shows what kind of a mind [he]200-mr. dobree must have . Thinking in that way about [a child]435-a child — [a mere child]1621-a mere child — and about [any man]1622-any man , [any _ decent _ man]1623-any _ decent _ man ; regarding it as possible , perhaps as natural ... worst of all , suggesting it of [some one standing in [my]0-i position toward [these children]3343-these children]1624-some one standing in my position toward these children ; as if [I]0-i might take advantage of [my]0-i opportunities to — to fall in love with [a child in [the schoolroom]1627-the schoolroom]1626-a child in the schoolroom ! ” [Boyne]145-boyne ’s words sounded in [his]145-boyne own ears as if they were being megaphoned at [him]145-boyne across the width of [the room]1180-the room . [He]145-boyne dropped down into the nearest chair , hot , angry , ashamed , with a throat as dry as if [he]145-boyne had been haranguing an open - air meeting on a dusty day . Opposite [him]145-boyne , [Mrs. Sellars]163-mrs. sellars remained with [her]163-mrs. sellars hands suspended above the letters . The sapphire burned at [him]145-boyne across the interval . “[193-martin] [Martin]193-martin ... but [you]193-martin _ are _ in love with [her]1626-a child in the schoolroom ! ” [she]163-mrs. sellars exclaimed . [She]163-mrs. sellars paused a moment , and then added in a quieter voice : “[0-i] [I]0-i believe [I]0-i ’ve always known it . ” [They]3678-they sat and looked at [each other]396-each other without speaking . At length [Boyne]145-boyne rose , and started to move around the table to where [she]163-mrs. sellars was sitting . “[0-i] This is ridiculous — ” [he]145-boyne began . [She]163-mrs. sellars held up [her]163-mrs. sellars hand , and the gesture , though evidently meant only to check the words on [his]145-boyne lips , had the effect also of arresting [his]145-boyne advance . [He]145-boyne felt self - conscious and clumsy , and dimly resented [her]163-mrs. sellars making [him]145-boyne feel so . [He]145-boyne was sure it was [she]163-mrs. sellars who had been ridiculous , not [he]145-boyne ; yet , curiously enough , the conviction brought [him]145-boyne no solace . Again [they]3678-they faced [each other]396-each other , guardedly , apprehensively , as if something fragile and precious , which [they]3678-they had been carrying together , had slipped between [their]3678-they fingers and been broken . [He]145-boyne felt that , if [he]145-boyne glanced at the floor , [he]145-boyne might see the glittering fragments .... [Mrs. Sellars]163-mrs. sellars was the first to recover [her]163-mrs. sellars self - possession . [She]163-mrs. sellars rose in [her]163-mrs. sellars turn , and going up to [Boyne]145-boyne laid [her]163-mrs. sellars hand on [his]145-boyne arm . “[0-i] [I]0-i wonder why [we]1628-we ’re trying to hurt [each other]396-each other ? ” [She]163-mrs. sellars looked at [him]145-boyne through moist lashes , and [he]145-boyne felt [himself]145-boyne a brute for not instantly taking [her]163-mrs. sellars in [his]145-boyne arms and obliterating [their]1628-we discussion with a kiss . But there lay the glittering fragments , and [he]145-boyne could not seem to reach to [her]163-mrs. sellars across them . “[0-i] Now [I]0-i know what [she]1630-she thinks of [Judith]127-judith , ” [he]145-boyne reflected savagely . “[1630-she] It ’s all [my]0-i fault , [Martin]193-martin ; [I]0-i know [I]0-i ’m nervous and stupid . ” [She]163-mrs. sellars was clasping [his]145-boyne arm , pleading with lifted eyes and lips . [Her]163-mrs. sellars self - abasement humiliated [him]145-boyne . “[0-i] If [she]1630-she really thinks what [she]1630-she says , why does n’t [she]1630-she kick [me]0-i out ? ” [he]145-boyne wondered . “[1630-she] [I]0-i suppose [I]0-i walked too far today , and got over - tired ; and what [Mr. Dobree]200-mr. dobree said startled [me]0-i , upset [me]0-i .... ” [He]145-boyne smiled . “[200-mr. dobree] [His]200-mr. dobree asking [you]0-i to marry [him]200-mr. dobree ? ” [She]0-i smiled back a little wearily . “[200-mr. dobree] No . But what [he]200-mr. dobree said about — about [your]0-i interest in [Judith]127-judith . [You]0-i must understand , [dear]2469-dear , that sometimes [your]0-i attitude about [those children]3144-those children is a little surprising to [people who do n’t know all the circumstances]1633-people who do n’t know all the circumstances . ” [Boyne]145-boyne felt [himself]145-boyne hardening again . “[0-i] What business is it of [people who do n’t know all the circumstances]1633-people who do n’t know all the circumstances ? _ [You]0-i _ do ; that ’s enough . ” [She]0-i seized at this with a distressing humility . “[0-i] Of course [I]0-i do , [dearest]3025-dearest ; of course it is . And [you]0-i ’ll try to forget [my]0-i stupid nerves , wo n’t [you]0-i ? Try to think of [me]0-i as [I]0-i am when there ’s nobody in [the world]307-the world but [you]0-i and [me]0-i ? ” [Her]0-i arms stole up to [his]145-boyne shoulders , [her]0-i hands met behind [his]145-boyne neck , and [she]0-i drew [his]145-boyne head down softly . “[0-i] If only it could always be like that ! ” As [their]3681-their lips touched [he]145-boyne shut [his]145-boyne eyes , and tried , with a violent effort of the will , to recall what [her]0-i kiss would have meant to [him]145-boyne on the far - off day when the news of [Sellars]163-mrs. sellars ’s death had overtaken [him]145-boyne somewhere in [the Nubian desert]3682-the nubian desert , and in the middle of the night [he]145-boyne had started awake , still clutching the letter , and crying out to [himself]145-boyne : “[0-i] At last .... ” XXII Next day , when [Boyne]145-boyne thought over the scene of the previous night , [he]145-boyne found for it all the excuses which occur to [a sensible man]3683-a sensible man in the glow of [his]145-boyne morning bath . It was all the result of idling and lack of hard exercise ; when [a working man]3684-a working man has had too long a holiday , and resting has become dawdling , [Satan]251-satan proverbially intervenes . But though at first [Boyne]145-boyne assumed all the blame , by the time [he]145-boyne began to shave [he]145-boyne had handed over a part to [Mrs. Sellars]163-mrs. sellars . After all , it was because of [her]0-i old - fashioned scruples , [her]0-i unwillingness to marry [him]145-boyne at once , and let [him]145-boyne get back to work , that [they]1637-their were still loitering in [the Dolomites]17-the dolomites . It probably was n’t safe for [middle - aged people]3685-middle - aged people to have too much leisure in which to weigh [each other]396-each other ’s faults and merits . But then , again , suddenly [he]145-boyne thought : “[0-i] If [we]1637-their ’d been married , and gone [home]290-home when [I]0-i wanted to , what would have become of [the children]505-the children ? ” It was undoubtedly because [Mrs. Sellars]163-mrs. sellars had insisted on prolonging [their]1637-their engagement that [Boyne]145-boyne had become involved in the Wheater problem ; but when [he]145-boyne reached this point in [his]145-boyne retrospect [he]145-boyne found [he]145-boyne could not preserve [his]145-boyne impartiality . It was impossible to face the thought of what might have happened to [the little Wheaters]130-the wheaters if chance had not put [him]145-boyne in [their]1637-their way .... After all , then , everything was for the best . All [he]145-boyne had to do was to persuade [Mrs. Sellars]163-mrs. sellars of it ( which ought not to be difficult , since it was a “[0-i] best ” of [her]163-mrs. sellars own devising ) , and to banish from [his]145-boyne mind the disturbing figure of [Mr. Dobree]200-mr. dobree . Perhaps — on second thoughts — [his]145-boyne irritability of the previous evening had been partly due to the suspicion that [Mrs. Sellars]163-mrs. sellars , for all [her]163-mrs. sellars affected indifference , was flattered by [Mr. Dobree]200-mr. dobree ’s proposal . “[1640-you] [You]1640-you never can tell — ” [Boyne]145-boyne concluded , and shrugged that possibility away too . The thought that [he]145-boyne might have had to desert [[his]145-boyne young friends]3620-his young friends in [their]3620-his young friends hour of distress , and had been able , instead , to stay and help [them]3620-his young friends , effaced all other considerations . So successfully did [he]145-boyne talk [himself]145-boyne over to this view that only one cloud remained on [his]145-boyne horizon . [Mrs. Sellars]163-mrs. sellars had said : “[1640-you] [I]0-i do n’t see how the biggest fortune , and [the cleverest lawyer in [the world]307-the world]1604-the cleverest lawyer in the world , could keep [the Wheaters]130-the wheaters from ordering [[their]130-the wheaters children]704-their children [home]290-home the day [they]130-the wheaters choose to ” ; and in saying it [she]163-mrs. sellars had put [her]163-mrs. sellars finger on [Boyne]145-boyne ’s inmost apprehension . [He]145-boyne had told [himself]145-boyne the same thing a hundred times ; but to hear it from [any one else]1619-any one else made the danger seem more pressing . It reminded [him]145-boyne that [the little Wheaters]130-the wheaters ’ hold on [him]145-boyne was not half as frail as [his]145-boyne own on [them]130-the wheaters , and that it was folly to indulge the illusion that [he]145-boyne could really direct or control [their]130-the wheaters fate . And meanwhile — ? Well , [he]145-boyne could only mark time ; thank heaven it was still [his]145-boyne to mark ! The Lido season had not yet reached its climax , and till it declined and fell [he]145-boyne was free to suppose that [its devotees]3689-its devotees would linger on , hypnotized . As between taking steps for an immediate divorce , and figuring to the last in the daily round of entertainment , [Boyne]145-boyne felt sure that [not one of [the persons concerned]3691-the persons concerned]3690-not one of the persons concerned would hesitate . [They]130-the wheaters could settle questions of business afterward ; and it was purely as business that [they]130-the wheaters regarded a matter in which the extent of the alimony was always the chief point of debate . And what could replace the excitement of a Longhi ball at [the Fenice]84-the fenice , or of a Marriage of [the Doge]3692-the doge to [the Adriatic]3693-the adriatic , mimed in [a reconstituted Bucentaur]3694-a reconstituted bucentaur by the rank and fashion of half [Europe]24-europe ? [No one]2415-no one would be leaving [Venice]8-venice yet . But , all the same , the days were flying . The increasing number of arrivals at [Cortina]34-cortina , the growing throng of motors on [all the mountain ways]3696-all the mountain ways , showed that before long fashion would be moving from [the seashore]677-the seashore to [the mountains]588-the mountains ; and when [the Lido]57-the lido broke up , what might not break up with it ? [Boyne]145-boyne felt that the question must at last be faced ; that [he]145-boyne must have a talk about it that very day with [Judith]127-judith . It was more than a month since [Judith]127-judith and [[her]127-judith flock]2626-her flock had appeared at [Cortina]34-cortina ; and [the various parents concerned]3700-the various parents concerned had promised [Boyne]145-boyne that [the children]505-the children should be left in [the Dolomites]17-the dolomites till the summer was over . But what was such a promise worth , and what did the phrase mean on lips so regardless of the seasons ? Nothing — [Boyne]145-boyne knew it . [He]145-boyne was conscious now that , during the last four weeks , [he]145-boyne had never gone down to [the _ Pension Rosenglüh _]3070-the _ pension rosenglüh _ without expecting to be told that a summons or a command had come from [the Lido]57-the lido . But so far there had been none . [The children]505-the children were protected by the fact that there was no telephone at [the _ pension _]880-the _ pension _ , and that [none of [[their]505-the children parents]507-their parents]3705-none of their parents was capable — except under the most extreme pressure — of writing a letter . When it was impossible to telephone [they]505-the children could , indeed , telegraph ; but even the inditing of a telegram required a concentration of mind which , [Boyne]145-boyne knew , would become increasingly difficult as the Lido season culminated . Telegrams did , of course , come , especially in the first days , both to [Boyne]145-boyne and to [Judith]127-judith : long messages from [Joyce]129-joyce about clothes and diet , rambling communications from [Lady Wrench]183-lady wrench , setting forth [her]127-judith rights and grievances in terms which , by the time [they]505-the children had passed through [two Italian telegraph - offices]3707-two italian telegraph - offices , were as confused as the thoughts in [her]127-judith own mind ; and lastly , a curt wire from [Cliffe Wheater]120-mrs. wheater to [Boyne]145-boyne : “[1640-you] Wish it definitely understood relinquish no rights whatever how is [Chipstone]142-chipstone reply paid . ” To all these communications [Boyne]145-boyne returned a comprehensive “[142-chipstone] All right , ” and , acting on [his]145-boyne advice , [Judith]127-judith did the same , merely adding particulars as to [the children]505-the children ’s health and happiness . “[142-chipstone] On the whole , [you]1645-you know , ” [she]0-i explained to [Boyne]145-boyne , “[1645-you] it ’s a relief to [them]1646-them all , now the thing ’s settled — [I]0-i always knew it would be . ” [She]0-i and [Terry]198-terry still cherished the hope that in the autumn [she]0-i would be permitted to take [the children]505-the children out to [Grandma Mervin]216-grandma mervin , in [America]2-america ; or that , failing permission , [she]0-i would be encouraged by [Boyne]145-boyne to carry [them]505-the children off secretly . With this in view , [she]0-i and [Miss Scope]147-miss scope saved up every penny [they]3710-they could of the allowance which [Cliffe Wheater]120-mrs. wheater had agreed to make , and which [Boyne]145-boyne dealt out to [them]3710-they once a week . But all these arrangements were so precarious , so dependent on the moods of [unreasonable and uncertain people]3711-unreasonable and uncertain people , that it seemed a miracle that [the little party]3712-the little party at [the _ Pension Rosenglüh _]3070-the _ pension rosenglüh _ was still undisturbed . Certainly , if it had been possible to reach [them]1647-they by telephone [they]1647-they would have been scattered long ago . “[0-i] As soon as [they]1647-they break up at [the Lido]1142-the lido [they]1647-they ’ll be after [you]1649-you , ” [Boyne]145-boyne had warned [Judith]127-judith from the first ; but [she]127-judith had always answered hopefully : “[1647-they] Oh , no : not till after [Cowes]182-cowes , if [they]1647-they still go [there]2439-there ; and if [they]1647-they do n’t , after [Venice]8-venice there ’s [Biarritz]29-biarritz . [You]1649-you ’ll see . And before [Biarritz]29-biarritz there ’s a fortnight in [Paris]42-paris for autumn clothes . ” [Cowes]182-cowes , in due course , had been relinquished , [the Lido]57-the lido exerting too strong a counter - attraction ; but after a few more weeks that show also would be packed away in [the lumber - room of spent follies]3714-the lumber - room of spent follies . The fact of having these questions always on [his]145-boyne mind kept [Boyne]145-boyne from being unduly disturbed by [his]145-boyne discussion of the previous evening with [Mrs. Sellars]163-mrs. sellars . In the wholesome light of morning a sentimental flurry between [two sensible people who were deeply attached to each other]3715-two sensible people who were deeply attached to each other seemed as nothing compared to the ugly reality perpetually hanging over [the little Wheaters]130-the wheaters ; and [he]145-boyne felt sure that [Mrs. Sellars]163-mrs. sellars would take the same view . [She]163-mrs. sellars did not disappoint [him]145-boyne . When [he]145-boyne presented [himself]145-boyne at the luncheon hour the very air of [the little sitting - room]1130-the little sitting - room breathed a new serenity ; it was as if [she]163-mrs. sellars had been out early to fill it with flowers . [Boyne]145-boyne was not used to delicate readjustments in [his]145-boyne sentimental relations . For so many years now [his]145-boyne feeling for [Rose Sellars]162-rose sellars had been something apart , like a beautiful picture on the wall of [a quiet room]3717-a quiet room ; and [his]145-boyne other amorous episodes had been too brief and simple for any great amount of manœuvring . [He]145-boyne was therefore completely reassured by the gaiety and simplicity of [her]163-mrs. sellars welcome , and thought to [himself]145-boyne once again that there was everything to be said in favour of a long social acquiescence . “[1651-a stupid woman] [A stupid woman]1651-a stupid woman , now , would insist on going over the whole thing again , like a blue - bottle that starts in banging about [the room]1180-the room after [you]1653-you ’re sure [you]1653-you ’ve driven it out of the window . ” There was nothing of the blue - bottle about [Mrs. Sellars]163-mrs. sellars ; and [she]163-mrs. sellars was timorously anxious that [Boyne]145-boyne should know it . But [her]163-mrs. sellars timidity was not base ; if [she]163-mrs. sellars submitted , [she]163-mrs. sellars submitted proudly . The only sign [she]163-mrs. sellars gave of a latent embarrassment was in [her]163-mrs. sellars too great ease , [her]163-mrs. sellars too blithe determination to deny it . But even this was minimised by the happy fact that [she]163-mrs. sellars had a piece of news for [him]145-boyne . [She]163-mrs. sellars did not tell [him]145-boyne what it was till lunch was over , and [they]3718-they were finishing [their]3718-they coffee in [the sitting - room]1172-the sitting - room : [she]163-mrs. sellars knew the importance of not disturbing [a man]308-a man ’s train of thought — even agreeably — while [he]308-a man is in the act of enjoying good food . [Boyne]145-boyne had lit [his]145-boyne cigar , and was meditating on the uniform excellence of the coffee [she]163-mrs. sellars managed to give [him]145-boyne , when [she]163-mrs. sellars said , with a little laugh : “[1651-a stupid woman] Only imagine — [Aunt Julia]203-aunt julia ’s on [the Atlantic]86-the atlantic ! [I]0-i had a radio this morning . [She]203-aunt julia says [she]203-aunt julia ’s coming over to [Paris]42-paris to see [you]1654-you . ” [Boyne]145-boyne had pictured [Aunt Julia]203-aunt julia — when [he]145-boyne could spare the time for such an evocation — as something solid , ponderous , essentially immovable . [She]163-mrs. sellars represented for [him]145-boyne the obstinate stability of old [New York]13-new york in the flux of new experiments . It was like being told that [Trinity Church]87-trinity church , for instance , was taking a Loretto - flight across [the Atlantic]86-the atlantic to see [him]145-boyne . [Mrs. Sellars]163-mrs. sellars laughed at [his]145-boyne incredulous stare . “[203-aunt julia] Are [you]1654-you surprised ? [I]0-i ’m not . [You]1654-you see , [Aunt Julia]203-aunt julia was always [the delicate sister]1655-the delicate sister , [the one who had to be nursed]1656-the one who had to be nursed . [Aunt Gertrude]252-aunt gertrude , [the strong one]1657-the strong one , who did the nursing , died last winter — and since then [Aunt Julia]203-aunt julia ’s been perfectly well . ” [They]1658-they agreed that such resurrections were not uncommon , and [Mrs. Sellars]163-mrs. sellars went so far as to declare that , if [she]163-mrs. sellars did n’t get to [Paris]42-paris in time to meet [Aunt Julia]203-aunt julia , [she]163-mrs. sellars was prepared to have [the latter]379-the latter charter [an aeroplane]3722-an aeroplane and descend on [Cortina]34-cortina . “[203-aunt julia] Indeed [we]1658-they ’re only protected by the fact that [I]0-i do n’t believe there ’s [any landing - field in [the Dolomites]17-the dolomites]1659-any landing - field in the dolomites . ” [She]0-i went on to say that [she]0-i would have to leave in a day or two , as [Aunt Julia]203-aunt julia , who was accustomed to having [her]203-aunt julia path smoothed for [her]203-aunt julia , had requested that [hotel rooms]3723-hotel rooms fulfilling all [her]203-aunt julia somewhat complicated requirements should be made ready for [her]203-aunt julia arrival , [a six - cylinder motor with balloon tires]3724-a six - cylinder motor with balloon tires and an irreproachable chauffeur engaged to meet [her]203-aunt julia at [the station]3725-the station , and [a doctor]3726-a doctor and [a masseuse]3727-a masseuse be found in attendance when [she]203-aunt julia arrived — as a result of which precautions [she]203-aunt julia hoped , after an interval of repose , to be well enough to occupy [herself]203-aunt julia with [[her]203-aunt julia niece]3728-her niece ’s plans . [Boyne]145-boyne gasped . “[0-i] [Good Lord]1660-good lord — what that cable must have cost [her]1661-she ! ” “[1660-good lord] Oh , it ’s not the cost that ever bothers [Aunt Julia]203-aunt julia , ” said [[Aunt Julia]203-aunt julia ’s niece]3729-aunt julia ’s niece with a certain deference . [Boyne]145-boyne laughed , and agreed that [Mrs. Sellars]163-mrs. sellars could not prudently refuse such a summons . Somehow it no longer offended [him]145-boyne that [she]3729-aunt julia ’s niece should obey it from motives so obviously interested . [He]145-boyne could not have said why , but it now seemed to [him]145-boyne natural enough that [she]3729-aunt julia ’s niece should hold [herself]3729-aunt julia ’s niece at the disposal of [a rich old aunt]3730-a rich old aunt . [He]145-boyne wondered whether it was because [her]3729-aunt julia ’s niece departure would serve to relieve a passing tension ; but [he]145-boyne dismissed this as a bit of idle casuistry . “[203-aunt julia] The point is that [she]1661-she ’s going — and that [she]1661-she and [I]0-i will probably be awfully glad to see [each other]396-each other when [she]1661-she gets back . ” [Mrs. Sellars]163-mrs. sellars cast a wistful look about [her]3729-aunt julia ’s niece . After a pause [she]0-i said : “[1661-she] [You]0-i do n’t know how [I]0-i hate to think that [our]1663-our good evenings in [this dear little room]1664-this dear little room are so nearly over , ” in a tone suggesting that [she]0-i had rather expected [Boyne]145-boyne to say it for [her]0-i , and that [he]145-boyne had somehow missed a cue . “[0-i] But why over ? Not for more than a week , [I]0-i hope ? [You]0-i ’re not going to let [yourself]0-i be permanently annexed by [Aunt Julia]203-aunt julia ? ” [She]0-i smiled a little perplexedly : evidently other plans were in [her]0-i mind , plans [she]0-i had pictured [him]145-boyne as instinctively divining . “[0-i] Not permanently ; but [I]0-i do n’t quite know when [I]0-i shall be able to leave [her]203-aunt julia — ” “[0-i] Oh , [I]0-i say , [[my]0-i dear]2807-my dear ! ” The perplexity lifted from [her]0-i smile : it seemed to reach out to [him]145-boyne like a promise . “[0-i] But then [I]0-i expect [you]0-i to join [me]0-i very soon . As soon as [Aunt Julia]203-aunt julia ’s blood - pressure has been taken , and [the doctor]1137-the doctor and [the masseuse]1667-the masseuse and [the chauffeur]1668-the chauffeur have been tested and passed upon . ” [Boyne]145-boyne listened in astonishment . It had never seriously occurred to [him]145-boyne that [he]145-boyne was to be involved in the ceremony of establishing [Aunt Julia]203-aunt julia on [European soil]3731-european soil . “[1137-the doctor] Oh , but look here — what earthly use should [I]0-i be ? Why should [I]0-i be butchered to make [Aunt Julia]203-aunt julia ’s holiday ? ” “[0-i] [You]0-i wo n’t be . It will be — almost the other way round . [I]0-i ’m going to do everything [I]0-i possibly can for [Aunt Julia]203-aunt julia ; everything to start [her]203-aunt julia successfully on [her]203-aunt julia European adventure . And then [I]0-i ’m going to present the bill . ” “[0-i] The bill ? ” [She]0-i nodded gaily . “[0-i] [You]0-i ’re the bill . [I]0-i ’m going to present [you]0-i , and say : ‘ Now [you]0-i ’ve seen [him]1669-him , can [you]0-i wonder that [I]0-i mean to marry [him]1669-him at once , whether [you]0-i like it or not ? ’ ” The words fell on a silence which [Boyne]145-boyne , for the moment , found it impossible to break . [Mrs. Sellars]163-mrs. sellars stood by [her]163-mrs. sellars writing - table , [her]163-mrs. sellars slender body leaning to [him]145-boyne , [her]163-mrs. sellars face lit with one of those gleams of lost youth which [he]145-boyne had once found so exquisite and poignant . [He]145-boyne found it so now , but with another poignancy . “[0-i] [You]0-i mean — [you]0-i mean — [you’ve]0-i changed [your]0-i mind about the date ? ” [He]145-boyne broke off , the words “[1673-her] of [our]1670-our marriage ” choking on [his]145-boyne lips . Through a mist of bewilderment [he]145-boyne saw the tender mockery of [her]1673-her smile , and knew how much courage it disguised . ( “[0-i] [I]0-i stand here like [a stock]1671-a stock — what [a brute]1672-a brute [she]1673-her ’ll think [me]0-i ! ” ) “[1673-her] Did [you]0-i imagine [I]0-i was [one of [the dreadful women who never change [their]1675-the dreadful women who never change their minds minds]1675-the dreadful women who never change their minds]1674-one of the dreadful women who never change their minds ? ” [She]1673-her came close , clasped [her]1673-her hands about [his]145-boyne arm , lifted [her]1673-her delicate face , still alight with expectation . The face said : “[0-i] Here [I]0-i am : to be cherished or shattered — ” and [he]145-boyne thought again of the glittering fragments [he]145-boyne had seen at [his]145-boyne feet the night before . [He]145-boyne detached [her]1673-her hands , and lifted them , one after another , to [his]145-boyne kiss . If only some word — if only the right word — would come to [him]145-boyne ! “[193-martin] [Martin]193-martin — don’t [you]193-martin _ want _ [me]0-i to change [my]0-i mind ? ” [she]1673-her suddenly challenged [him]145-boyne . [He]145-boyne held [her]1673-her hands against [his]145-boyne breast , caressing them . “[193-martin] [Dear]2469-dear , first of all , [I]0-i do n’t want to be the cause of [you]2469-dear doing anything that might offend [[your]2469-dear aunt]1677-your aunt ... that might interfere ... in any way ... with [her]1677-your aunt views .... ” No ; [he]145-boyne could n’t go on ; the words strangled [him]145-boyne . [He]145-boyne was too sure that [she]1673-her was aware they did not express what [he]145-boyne was thinking , were spoken only to gain time . But with a gentle tenacity [she]1673-her pursued : “[193-martin] It ’s awfully generous of [you]193-martin to think of that . But do n’t [you]193-martin suppose , [dear]2469-dear , [I]0-i ’ve been miserable at asking [you]193-martin to linger on here when [I]0-i ’ve always known that what [you]193-martin wanted was to be married at once , and get back to work ? [I]0-i ’ve been imprisoned in [my]0-i past — [I]0-i see it now ; [I]0-i had become [the slave of all those years of conformity [you]1680-he used to reproach [me]0-i with]1679-the slave of all those years of conformity you used to reproach me with . For a long time [I]0-i could n’t get out of [their]1680-he shadow . But [you]1680-he ’ve opened [my]0-i eyes — [you’ve]1680-he set [me]0-i free . How monstrous to have waited so long for happiness , and then to be afraid to seize it when it comes ! ” [Her]1680-he arms stole up and drew [him]1680-he . “[0-i] [I]0-i ’m not afraid now , [Martin]193-martin . [You]1680-he ’ve taught [me]0-i not to be . Henceforth [I]0-i mean to think of [you]1680-he first , not of [Aunt Julia]203-aunt julia . [I]0-i mean to marry [you]1680-he as soon as it can be done . [I]0-i do n’t suppose the formalities take very long in [Paris]42-paris , do they ? Then , as soon as [we]1681-we ’re married , [we]1681-we ’ll sail for [home]290-home . ” [He]1680-he listened in a kind of stupor , saying inwardly : “[203-aunt julia] It ’s not that [I]0-i love [her]203-aunt julia less ; it ca n’t be that [I]0-i love [her]203-aunt julia less . It ’s only that everything that happens between [us]1681-we always seems to happen at the wrong time . ” The silence prolonged itself , on [her]162-rose sellars side stretched and straining , on [his]1680-he built up like a wall , opaque , impenetrable . From beyond it came [her]162-rose sellars little far - off laugh . “[2469-dear] [Dear]2469-dear , [I]0-i ’m utterly in [your]2469-dear hands , [you]2469-dear see ! ” Evidently there had to be an answer to that . “[162-rose sellars] [Rose]162-rose sellars — ” [he]1680-he began . Pretty as [her]162-rose sellars name was , [he]1680-he hardly ever called [her]162-rose sellars by it ; [he]1680-he had always felt [her]162-rose sellars too close to [him]1680-he to need a name . [She]162-rose sellars looked up in surprise . [He]1680-he made a fresh start . “[162-rose sellars] But [you]2469-dear see , [darling]3107-darling , how things are — ” A little tremor ran across [her]162-rose sellars face . “[2469-dear] What things ? ” “[2469-dear] [You]2469-dear know that , after [you]2469-dear ’d refused to consider the possibility of [our]1685-our getting married at once , [I]0-i pledged [myself]0-i .... ” The tremor ceased , and [her]162-rose sellars face once more became smooth and impenetrable . [He]1680-he found [himself]1680-he repeating to [vacancy]253-vacancy : “[0-i] [I]0-i pledged [myself]0-i .... ” [She]162-rose sellars drew quietly away , and sat down at a little distance from [him]1680-he . “[2469-dear] [You]2469-dear ’re talking about [your]2469-dear odd experiment with [the Wheater children]873-the wheater children ? ” “[2469-dear] It ’s more than an experiment . When [I]0-i saw [the parents in [Venice]8-venice]1687-the parents in venice [I]0-i told [them]1687-the parents in venice , as [you]2469-dear know , that [I]0-i ’d be responsible for the welfare of [the children]505-the children as long as [they]505-the children were left with [me]0-i . ” “[0-i] As long as [they]505-the children were left with [you]0-i ! For life , perhaps , then ? ” [She]0-i leaned forward , [her]0-i face drawn with the valiant effort of [her]0-i smile . “[193-martin] [Martin]193-martin ! Is all this serious ? It ca n’t be ! [You]193-martin ca n’t really be asking [me]0-i to understand that all [our]1689-our plans — [our]1689-our whole future , [yours]2469-dear and [mine]0-i — are to depend , for an indefinite length of time , on the whim of [two or three chance acquaintances of [yours]2469-dear who are too heartless and self - engrossed to look after [[their]1690-two or three chance acquaintances of yours who are too heartless and self - engrossed to look after their own children own children]1691-their own children]1690-two or three chance acquaintances of yours who are too heartless and self - engrossed to look after their own children ! ” [Boyne]145-boyne paused a moment ; then [he]145-boyne said : “[1689-our] [We]1689-our had no plans — [I]0-i mean , no immediate plans — when [I]0-i entered into the arrangement . It was by [your]193-martin own choice that — ” “[0-i] [My]0-i own choice ! Well , then , [my]0-i own choice , now , is that [we]1689-our should have plans , immediately . ” [She]193-martin stood up , trembling a little . [She]193-martin was very pale , and [her]193-martin thin eyebrows drew a straight black bar across [her]193-martin forehead . “[193-martin] [Martin]193-martin — [I]0-i ask [you]193-martin to come with [me]0-i at once to [Paris]42-paris . ” “[0-i] At once ? But just now [you]193-martin said in a week or two — ” “[193-martin] And now [I]0-i say at once : to - morrow . ” [He]3732-he stood leaning against the chimney , as far from [her]193-martin as [the little room]3733-the little room allowed . A tide of resistance rose in [him]3732-he . “[0-i] [I]0-i ca n’t come to - morrow . ” [He]3732-he was conscious that [she]193-martin was making an intense effort to steady [her]193-martin quivering nerves . “[193-martin] [Martin]193-martin ... [I]0-i do n’t want to be unreasonable .... ” “[0-i] [You]0-i ’re never unreasonable , ” [he]3732-he said patiently . “[193-martin] [You]193-martin mean it might have been better if [I]0-i were ! ” [she]193-martin flashed back , crimsoning . “[193-martin] Do n’t be — now , ” [he]3732-he pleaded . “[193-martin] No . ” [She]193-martin paused . “[193-martin] Very well . Come to [Paris]42-paris in a few days , then . ” “[193-martin] Look here , [dear]2469-dear — all this is of no use . No earthly use . [I]0-i ca n’t come in a few days , any more than [I]0-i can come to - morrow . [I]0-i ca n’t desert [these children]3343-these children till [their]3343-these children future is settled in one way or another . [I]0-i ’ve said [I]0-i ’d stick to [them]3343-these children , and [I]0-i mean to . If [I]0-i turned [my]0-i back on [them]3343-these children now [they]3343-these children ’d lose [their]3343-these children last chance of being able to stay together . ” [She]0-i received this with bent head and hands clasped stiffly across [her]0-i knee ; but suddenly [her]0-i self - control broke down . “[193-martin] But , [Martin]193-martin , are [you]193-martin mad ? What business is it of [yours]193-martin , anyhow , what becomes of [these children]3343-these children ? ” “[0-i] [I]0-i do n’t know , ” [he]3734-he said simply . “[0-i] [You]0-i do n’t know — [you]0-i do n’t know ? ” “[0-i] No ; [I]0-i only feel it ’s got to be . [I]0-i ’m pledged . [I]0-i ca n’t get round it . ” “[0-i] [You]0-i ca n’t get round it because [you]0-i do n’t want to . [You]0-i ’re pledged because [you]0-i want to be . [You]0-i want to be because [Mr. Dobree]200-mr. dobree was right ... because .... ” “[162-rose sellars] [Rose]162-rose sellars , take care , ” [he]200-mr. dobree interrupted , very low . “[162-rose sellars] Take care ? At this hour ? Of what ? For whom ? All [I]0-i care for is to know the truth .... ” “[0-i] [I]0-i ’m telling [you]0-i the truth . ” “[0-i] [You]0-i may think [you]0-i are . But the truth is something very different — something [you]0-i ’re not conscious of [yourself]0-i , perhaps ... not clearly .... ” “[0-i] [I]0-i believe [I]0-i ’m telling [you]0-i the whole truth . ” “[0-i] That when [I]0-i ask [you]0-i to choose between [me]0-i and [the Wheater children]873-the wheater children , [you]0-i choose [the Wheater children]873-the wheater children — out of philanthropy ? ” “[0-i] [I]0-i did n’t say out of philanthropy . [I]0-i said [I]0-i did n’t know .... ” “[0-i] If [you]0-i do n’t know , [I]0-i do . [You]0-i ’re in love with [Judith Wheater]127-judith , and [you]0-i ’re trying to persuade [yourself]0-i that [you]0-i ’re still in love with [me]0-i . ” [He]2469-dear lifted [his]2469-dear hands to [his]2469-dear face , and covered [his]2469-dear eyes , as if from some intolerable vision [she]162-rose sellars had summoned to [them]3735-them . “[0-i] Do n’t [Rose]162-rose sellars , for [the Lord]1697-the lord ’s sake .... Do n’t let [’s]1698-’s say stupid things — ” “[1698-’s] But , [dear]2469-dear , [I]0-i must . ” [She]162-rose sellars got up and came close to [him]2469-dear again ; [he]2469-dear felt [her]162-rose sellars hands on [his]2469-dear arm . “[0-i] Listen , [Martin]193-martin . [I]0-i love [you]193-martin too much not to want to help [you]193-martin . Try to feel that about [me]0-i , wo n’t [you]193-martin ? Then everything will be so much easier . ” “[193-martin] Yes . ” “[193-martin] Try to understand [your]193-martin own feelings — that ’s the best way of sparing [mine]0-i . [I]0-i want the truth , that ’s all . Try to see the truth , and face it with [me]0-i — it ’s all [I]0-i ask . ” [He]2469-dear dropped [his]2469-dear hands , and turned [his]2469-dear discouraged eyes on [her]193-martin . But [he]2469-dear could only feel that [he]2469-dear and [she]193-martin were farther apart than when [he]2469-dear had last looked at [her]193-martin ; all the rest was confusion and obscurity . “[0-i] [I]0-i do n’t know what the truth , as [you]193-martin call it , is ; [I]0-i swear [I]0-i do n’t ; but [I]0-i know it ’s not what [you]193-martin think . [Judith]127-judith ’s as much [a child]435-a child to [me]0-i as [the others]2515-the others — that [I]0-i swear to [you]193-martin . ” “[0-i] Then , [dear]2469-dear — ” “[0-i] Then , [I]0-i ’ve got to stick to [them]1703-them all the same , ” [he]2469-dear repeated doggedly . For a time [the two]395-the two continued to stand in silence , with eyes averted , like [people straining to catch some far - off sound which will signal relief from a pressing peril]3737-people straining to catch some far - off sound which will signal relief from a pressing peril . Then , slowly , [Boyne]145-boyne turned to [Mrs. Sellars]163-mrs. sellars . [His]145-boyne eyes rested on [her]163-mrs. sellars profile , so thin , drawn , bloodless , that a fresh pang shot through [him]145-boyne . [He]145-boyne had often mocked at [himself]145-boyne as [a man who , in spite of all [his]145-boyne wanderings , had never had a real adventure]3738-a man who , in spite of all his wanderings , had never had a real adventure ; but now [he]145-boyne saw that [he]145-boyne [himself]145-boyne had been [one]2514-one , had been [Rose Sellars]162-rose sellars ’s Great Adventure , the risk and the enchantment of [her]163-mrs. sellars life . While [she]163-mrs. sellars had continued , during the weary years of [her]163-mrs. sellars marriage , to be blameless , exemplary , patient and heroically gay , the thought of [Boyne]145-boyne was storing up treasures for [her]163-mrs. sellars which [she]163-mrs. sellars would one day put out [her]163-mrs. sellars hand and take — no matter how long [she]163-mrs. sellars might have to wait . [Her]163-mrs. sellars patience , [Boyne]145-boyne knew , was endless — it was as long as [her]163-mrs. sellars hair . [She]163-mrs. sellars had trained [herself]163-mrs. sellars to go on waiting for happiness , day after day , month after month , year after year , with the same air of bright unruffled vigilance , like a tireless animal waiting for its prey . One day [her]163-mrs. sellars prey , [her]163-mrs. sellars happiness , would appear , and [she]163-mrs. sellars would snap it up ; and on that day there would be no escape from [her]163-mrs. sellars .... It was terrible , it was hideous , to be picturing [her]163-mrs. sellars distress as something grasping and predatory ; it was more painful still to be entering so acutely into [her]163-mrs. sellars feelings while a central numbness paralysed [his]145-boyne own . All around this numbness there was a great margin of pity and of comprehension ; but [he]145-boyne knew this was not [the region by way of which [he]145-boyne could reach [her]163-mrs. sellars]3740-the region by way of which he could reach her . [She]163-mrs. sellars who had always lived the life of reason would never forgive [him]145-boyne if [he]145-boyne called upon [her]163-mrs. sellars reason now .... “[162-rose sellars] [Rose]162-rose sellars — ” [he]145-boyne appealed to [her]162-rose sellars . [She]162-rose sellars turned and [he]145-boyne saw [her]162-rose sellars face , composed , remodelled , suffused with a brilliancy like winter starlight . [Her]162-rose sellars lips formed a smiling : “[2469-dear] [Dear]2469-dear ? ” “[162-rose sellars] [Rose]162-rose sellars — ” [She]162-rose sellars took [his]145-boyne hand with the lightest pressure . “[162-rose sellars] [Dearest]3025-dearest , what utter nonsense [we]1706-we ’ve both been talking ! Of course [I]0-i do n’t mean that [you]162-rose sellars ’re to desert [the Wheater children]873-the wheater children for [me]0-i — and of course [you]162-rose sellars do n’t mean that [you]162-rose sellars ’re to desert [me]0-i for [them]873-the wheater children ; do [you]162-rose sellars ? [I]0-i believe [I]0-i understand all [you]162-rose sellars feel ; all [your]162-rose sellars fondness for the poor little things . [I]0-i should shiver at [you]162-rose sellars if [you]162-rose sellars had n’t grown to love [them]873-the wheater children ! But [you]162-rose sellars and [I]0-i have managed to get [each other]396-each other all on edge , [I]0-i do n’t know how . Do n’t [you]162-rose sellars feel what a mistake it would be to go in and out of this question any longer ? [I]0-i have an idea [I]0-i could find a solution almost at once , if only [I]0-i were n’t trying to so hard . And so could [you]162-rose sellars , no doubt . ” [She]0-i paused , a little breathlessly , and then resumed [her]0-i eager monologue . “[162-rose sellars] Let ’s say goodbye till to - morrow , shall [we?—and]1709-their produce [our]1709-their respective plans of action when [we]1709-their meet again . And do n’t forget that the problem may solve itself without regard to [us]1709-their , and at any minute . ” [She]0-i had caught at the last splinter of the rock of Reason still visible above the flood ; and there [she]0-i clung , dauntless , unbeaten , uttering the right , the impartial word with lips that pined and withered for [his]3741-he kiss .... “[2807-my dear] Oh , [[my]0-i dear]2807-my dear , ” [he]3741-he murmured . “[2807-my dear] To - morrow ? ” “[2807-my dear] Yes — to - morrow . ” Before [he]3741-he could take [her]0-i in [his]3741-he arms [she]0-i had slipped out of reach , and softly , adroitly closed the door on [him]3741-he . Alone on [the landing]3742-the landing [he]3741-he was left with the sense that that deft gesture had shut [him]3741-he up with [her]0-i forever . XXIII It was growing more and more evident to [Boyne]145-boyne that [he]145-boyne could recover [his]145-boyne old vision of [Mrs. Sellars]163-mrs. sellars only when [they]1709-their were apart . [He]145-boyne began to think this must be due to [his]145-boyne having loved [her]0-i so long from a distance , having somehow , in consequence of [their]1709-their separation , established with [her]0-i an ideal relation to which [her]0-i slightest misapprehension , [her]0-i least failure to say just what [he]145-boyne expected , was a recurring menace . At first the surprise of finding [her]0-i , after [his]145-boyne long absence , so much younger and more vivid than [his]145-boyne remembrance , the glow of long - imagined caresses , the whole enchanting harmony of [her]0-i presence , had hushed the inner discord . But though [she]0-i was dearer to [him]145-boyne than ever , all free communication seemed to have ceased between [them]1709-their — [he]145-boyne could regain it only during those imaginary conversations in which it was [he]145-boyne who sustained both sides of the dialogue . This was what happened when [he]145-boyne had walked off the pain and bewilderment of [their]1709-their last talk . For two hours [he]145-boyne tramped the heights , unhappy , confused , struggling between the sense of [her]0-i unreasonableness and of [his]145-boyne own predicament ; then gradually there stole back on [him]145-boyne the serenity always associated with the silent sessions of [his]145-boyne thought and [hers]0-i . On what seemed to [him]145-boyne the fundamental issues — questions of fairness , kindness , human charity in the widest meaning — when had [she]0-i ever failed [him]145-boyne in these wordless talks ? [His]145-boyne position with regard to [the Wheater children]873-the wheater children ( had n’t [he]145-boyne admitted it to [her]0-i ? ) was unreasonable , indefensible , was whatever else [she]0-i chose to call it ; yes , but it was also human , and that would touch [her]0-i in the end . [He]145-boyne had no doubt that when [they]1709-their met the next day [she]0-i would have [her]0-i little solution ready , and be prepared to smile with [him]145-boyne over [their]1709-their needless perturbation . The thought of [her]0-i deep submissive passion , which contrasted so sharply with [his]145-boyne own uneasy self - assertiveness , was the only anxiety that remained with [him]145-boyne . [He]145-boyne knew now how much [she]0-i loved [him]145-boyne — but did [he]145-boyne know how much [he]145-boyne loved [her]0-i ? Supposing , for instance , that on getting back to [[his]145-boyne hotel]925-his hotel , now , this very evening , [he]145-boyne should find a line telling [him]145-boyne that [she]0-i had decided for both [their]1709-their sakes to break [their]1709-their engagement : well , could [he]145-boyne honestly say that it would darken earth and [heaven]3745-heaven for [him]145-boyne ? Mortified , hurt , at a loose end — all this [he]145-boyne would be ; already the tender flesh of [his]145-boyne vanity was shrinking , and under it [he]145-boyne felt the thrust of wounded affection . But that was all — in the balance how little ! [He]145-boyne got back late to [the hotel]1085-the hotel , and walked unheedingly past the letter - rack toward which , at that hour , it was usual to glance for the evening mail . [The porter]3050-the porter called to [him]145-boyne , waving a letter . The envelope bore the [New York]13-new york post - mark , and in the upper corner [Boyne]145-boyne recognised the name of [the big firm of contracting engineers to whom [he]145-boyne had owed some of [his]145-boyne most important jobs]3748-the big firm of contracting engineers to whom he had owed some of his most important jobs . [They]3748-the big firm of contracting engineers to whom he had owed some of his most important jobs still wrote now and then to consult [him]145-boyne : no doubt this letter , which had been forwarded by [[his]145-boyne London bankers]3749-his london bankers , was of that nature . [He]145-boyne pushed it into [his]145-boyne pocket , deciding to read it after [he]145-boyne had dined . And then [he]145-boyne proceeded to dine , alone in a corner of [the unfashionable restaurant of [[his]145-boyne hotel]925-his hotel]3750-the unfashionable restaurant of his hotel , of which the tables with [their]3748-the big firm of contracting engineers to whom he had owed some of his most important jobs thick crockery and clumsy water - carafes seemed like homely fragments of a recently - disjoined _ table d’hôte _ , the long old - fashioned hotel table at which [travellers]3752-travellers used to be seated in [[his]145-boyne parents]3753-his parents ’ day . A coarse roll lay by [his]145-boyne plate , the table bore a bunch of half - faded purply - pink cosmos in an opaque blue vase : everything about [him]145-boyne was ugly and impersonal , yet [he]145-boyne hugged [himself]145-boyne for not being at [the _ châlet _ table]3754-the _ châlet _ table , with [its]3754-the _ châlet _ table air of exquisite rusticity , [its]3754-the _ châlet _ table bowl of cunningly - disposed wild flowers , the shaded candles , the amusing food . Yes ; and [he]145-boyne was glad , too , not to be sharing the little Wheaters ’ pudding at the _ Pension Rosenglüh _ ; [he]145-boyne was suddenly aware of an intense unexpected satisfaction in being for once alone , [[his]145-boyne own master]3755-his own master , with [no one]2415-no one that [he]145-boyne need be on [his]145-boyne guard against or at [his]145-boyne best before ; [no one to be tormented or enchanted by]3757-no one to be tormented or enchanted by , [no one to listen to and answer]3758-no one to listen to and answer . “[2807-my dear] Decidedly , [I]0-i ’m [a savage]1711-a savage , ” [he]145-boyne thought , emptying [his]145-boyne plateful of savourless soup with an appetite [he]145-boyne was almost ashamed of . The moral of it , obviously , was that [he]145-boyne had been idle too long , that what [he]145-boyne was thirsting for at this very moment was not more rest but more work , and that the idea of giving up [his]145-boyne life of rough and toilsome activity for the security of [an office in [New York]13-new york]3759-an office in new york , as [he]145-boyne had aspired to do a few short months ago , now seemed intolerable . Too old for the fatigue and hardships of [an engineer]3760-an engineer ’s life ? Why , it was the fatigues and the hardships which , physically speaking , had given the work its zest , just as the delicate mathematical calculations had provided its intellectual stimulus . The combination of two such sources of interest , so rare in other professions , was apparently what [he]145-boyne needed to keep [him]145-boyne straight , curb [his]145-boyne excitable imagination , discipline [his]145-boyne nerves , and make [him]145-boyne wake up every morning to a steady imperturbable view of life . After dinner , sitting in [the dreary little lounge]3761-the dreary little lounge , as [he]145-boyne lit [his]145-boyne pipe and pulled the letter from [his]145-boyne pocket [he]145-boyne thought : “[0-i] [I]0-i wish to [God]214-god it was an order to start for [Tierra del Fuego]88-tierra del fuego ! ” It was nothing of the sort , of course : merely an inquiry for the address of [a young engineer who had been [[Boyne]145-boyne ’s assistant]3763-boyne ’s assistant a few years earlier , and whom [the firm in question]3764-the firm in question had lost sight of]3762-a young engineer who had been boyne ’s assistant a few years earlier , and whom the firm in question had lost sight of . [They]3765-they had been struck with [Boyne]145-boyne ’s estimate of [the young man]798-the young man ’s ability , and thought [they]3765-they might have an interesting piece of work for [him]145-boyne , if [he]145-boyne happened to be available , and was not scared by hardships and responsibility . [Boyne]145-boyne put the letter into [his]145-boyne pocket , leaned back in [his]145-boyne chair , and thought : “[214-god] [God]214-god ! [I]0-i wish [I]0-i was [his]1712-his age and just starting — for anywhere . ” [His]145-boyne mind turned round and round this thought for the rest of the evening . Perhaps [he]145-boyne could make [Mrs. Sellars]163-mrs. sellars understand that , after all , [he]145-boyne had made a mistake in supposing [he]145-boyne had reached the age for sedentary labours . Once [they]3765-they were married [she]163-mrs. sellars would surely see that , for [his]145-boyne soul ’s sake , and until the remainder of [his]145-boyne youth was used up , [she]163-mrs. sellars must let [him]145-boyne go off on these remote exciting expeditions which seemed the only cure for — for what ? Well , for the creeping grayness of age , no doubt . The fear of that must be what ailed [him]145-boyne . At any rate [he]145-boyne must get away ; [he]145-boyne must . As soon as the fate of [the little Wheaters]130-the wheaters was decided , and [he]145-boyne and [Rose]162-rose sellars were married , and [he]145-boyne had established [her]162-rose sellars in [New York]13-new york , [he]145-boyne must get back into [the glorious soul - releasing world of girders and abutments]3767-the glorious soul - releasing world of girders and abutments , of working stresses , curvatures and grades . [She]163-mrs. sellars had talked of having [her]163-mrs. sellars little plan ready for [him]145-boyne the next day . Well , [he]145-boyne would have one for [her]163-mrs. sellars , at any rate ; this big comprehensive one .
